title: _.defaultsDeep vs _.merge inconsistency
body:
So I have code where I need to override the `.toString` accessor for a plain object.
An example is the following: 
```js
let x = { foo: 'bar' }
x.toString = function() { return this.foo; };
console.log(x + ""); // outputs 'bar' (correct)
```
..which, as intended, outputs the value of a property of the object.
I, however, need to merge this object with another because I have some default values.

It makes sense to me that if I do:
```js
let y = _.defaultsDeep({}, x);
console.log(y + ""); // outputs "[object Object]"
```
I lose my string converter, because `.toString` is a built-in method that I overwrote, and it is already defined in `{}` and therefore not overridden. 

Correctly, `_.merge` does preserve this string accessor because in the case of a property being defined in multiple arguments, the rightmost one wins.

An odd artifact appears though, if I use `_.defaultsDeep` on a multi-dimensional object like so:
```js
let y = { x: x };
let z = _.defaultsDeep({}, y);
console.log(y.x + ""); // outputs "[object Object]"
```
The expected output here is `bar` again, since the empty object in the first argument has no property `x` set and thus `z.x` should be identical to `x`. 

This, however, does not happen.

title: How to filter keys of an object?
body:
I have a json array format:

```
[{
  aaa: "aaa",
  bbb: "bbb",
  ccc: "ccc",
  ddd: "ddd",
  eee: "eee"
}]
```

How can I get the specific item from the json array?

```
[{
  aaa: "aaa",
  ddd: "ddd",
  eee: "eee"
}]
```

I tried with `_.get`:

```
const test = [{
  aaa: "aaa",
  bbb: "bbb",
  ccc: "ccc",
  ddd: "ddd",
  eee: "eee"
}];

const keys = ['aaa', 'ddd', 'eee'];

console.log(_.get(test, keys))
```

title: Why array filter does not check for undefined values?
body:
See this code:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/filter.js
It ignores undefined values, why?

The native filter is not invoked for indexes which have been deleted or which have never been assigned values.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter

how to build the directory of 'lib'

title: Add (inc) and (dec) math functions!
body:
By "decrement" we mean decrease by one.  Say you want to decrement all elements of an array:
 (any traversable)

`maxa = _.zipWith(maxa, x => {return x - 1;})`

Currently you need to define your own function.  However, if we add a "math" util function _.dec, we can make the above code arguably more elegant:

`maxa = _.zipWith(maxa, _.dec)`

title: Small textual issue.
body:
Link : https://lodash.com/docs/2.4.2#filter
First line says  : Iterates over elements of a collection, returning an array of all elements the callback returns *truey* for.

If *truey* was intentional please feel free to mark it as invalid. :)

title: isEmpty returns unexpected value on Number objects
body:
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.10#isEmpty
> Checks if value is an empty object, collection, map, or set.

```
let x = new Number(-1)
typeof x
> "object"
_.isEmpty(x)
> true
```

Edit:

Apparently this is because of the second line in the docs:
> Objects are considered empty if they have no own enumerable string keyed properties.

```
x.myNewProp = 'ok'
_.isEmpty(x)
> false
```

title: Using map on array of objects breaks breaks in flow (React)
Feature request: rsplit
body:
Coming from Python to Javascript, I miss this function.

I'm not the only one. Note the 11 upvotes on this question:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5202085/javascript-equivalent-of-pythons-rsplit

Multiple potential implementations are provided in the StackOverflow thread.

title: Poor performance from "uniq" on large arrays in IE11
body:
When running `uniq` on a large array (e.g. 25k items), the performance is really poor in IE11. Using a crudely written for-loop with an intermediate Set results in much better performance.

See the following jsperf (https://jsperf.com/lodash-uniq-vs-for-loop-and-set/1):
![screenshot-firefox](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/154842/44991127-74d57680-af93-11e8-89f1-79be37e4b715.png)
![screenshot-ie11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/154842/44991200-a2babb00-af93-11e8-8c37-e56671690b3c.png)

The culprits are `baseUniq` and `createSet`. `createSet` becomas a noop function in IE11 since it doesn't support the Set constructor with arguments, and thus `baseUniq` falls back to its own implementation.

I propose to update `createSet` to handle browsers which doesn't support the constructor with arguments.

I'm happy to create a PR if you are open for it.

title: Merge two json objects into single object
body:
I have two json objects like these:

```
var object = [{name: 'John', age: 23}]
var other  = [{name: 'Wilmer', age: 17}]
```

I want them merge into single json object by using `_.merge` method. I'd rather not use concat().

`[{"name":"John","age":23},{"name":"Wilmer","age":17}]`

but it doesn't contain the destination object. Is there any other way to merge this?

`var finalObj = _.merge(object, other);`

title: Add reverce function calls order for debounce method
_.has functionality changed in 4.17.5 breaking backwards compatibility
isFlattenable and isArrayLikeObject
body:
Hi!

I have a (somewhat historical) question about `isFlattenable` and the use of `isArrayLikeObject`.  

The context is: I am using [MobX](https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx), and they have something called an `ObservableArray`.  It's an object which has a `length` property.

When I tried using this object as a value in `_.concat`, I observed that it wasn't flattened as I expected. Given its `length` property, it should work fine with `arrayPush`.  Investigating why, I found the `isFlattenable` utility and its `spreadableSymbol` check.

Unfortunately, the `ObservableArray` doesn't support `isConcatSpreadable` yet, for some [stated reasons](https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx/issues/1490#issuecomment-379812490).  There are [concrete indications](https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx/commit/109eaf4a47e5e057bd5f0999364521078266cdaf#diff-011c6ab8f1ccbfa906d790a35a44dfd3) that MobX will support the symbol in their next major release, which will resolve this surprise.

But I also found that `isFlattenable` [used to support](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/05c32044e970cd04f9c8422531217e9a9af77b4f) array-like objects in general (a check that `ObservableArray` fulfills).  What was the reason that this condition was removed?

title: Why does startCase return three words as output when the input is two?
_.explode
body:
It would be great if there was `_.split` alternative which is consistent with `.join` so you could:

```
const arr = ['one', 'two']

assert.strictDeepEquals(_.explode(arr.join(' '), ' '), arr)
```

title: Add extended and supplement combining marks ranges
body:
I wasn't sure if there was a reason the same variables were defined in multiple files, so I left them as is, and added in all relevant locations. Fixes #3930.

This adds tne other combining marks ranges, though please note that this regex does not fully follow the UAX 29 algorithm for counting grapheme clusters which is quite a bit more complex. But this is hopefully a little improvement :)

title: setWith/baseSet customizer: not enought information from provided arguments
body:
Hello,

`baseSet` takes a _customizer_ function that can set the object for path elements that don't exist. If the newValue is undefined, `baseSet` looks at the next path element and creates either an empty object or array.

The problem is that the custom function has no access to the path, so it can't know if it needs to create an array or object to emulate the default way `baseSet` works.

What I'm really trying to do is use `setWith` to invoke Vue.set() to insert an empty object/array instead of a bare empty object `{}`, because Vue needs some magic to detect new keys and stay reactive.

It would be helpful if the _customizer_ function would also be able to know if it needs to provide an object or an array, and I don't think there's a way to do that with the current arguments.

title: Include extra combining ranges
body: rsComboRange  in UnicodeSize.js does not include the Combining Diacritical Marks Extended (1AB0–1AFF) and Combining Diacritical Marks Supplement (1DC0–1DFF) ranges – I'm guessing these should also be included?

title: Unclear fp documentation section https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide#exceptions-to-the-rules
body:
I'm trying to convert `invokeMap` to `invokeArgsMap` with no success

Code example
```
const _ = require('lodash');
const fp = require('lodash/fp');

const data = [[1], [2]];
console.log(_.invokeMap(data, 'map', v => v * 2)); // [[ 2 ], [ 4 ]]
console.log(fp.invokeArgsMap(v => v * 2)('map')(data)); // error
```

`invokeArgsMap` has fixed arity of three, so I'm using the same pattern as from example for `padCharsStart`

But there is exception in section below: `Methods that expect an array as their last or only argument:`
This is unclear note for me, could you please give an example for this exception?

Thanks!

title: Is this a valid Group by Multiple or am I re-inventing the wheel?
Add docs for edge cases: slice with end > array.length
body:
When slice is called with end > array.length, array.length is used (which is expected).

I'd like to be able to read this in the [docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.10#slice), instead of reading it in the [sources](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.10/lodash.js#L4072).

Since it currently isn't documented, I'm obliged to truncate end myself or I'm using undefined (or at least undocumented) behaviour. Because the feature currently is undocumented, it could be removed in a future version, which would break my code if I were to rely on it.

Is there an interest in documenting the edge case behaviour? A negative number (between -array.length and 0) for end is also allowed, for instance.

Is there a repository for the documentation, so people can add pull requests for them too?

title: Prevent ReDoS
body: To fix https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3359, modified reHasUnicodeWord to remove an unnecessary comma which made the regex greedy, this is only a test regex and not a matching regex. Added unit tests, this now should run under 5 ms instead of over 1000 ms for huge 50k+ char words.

title: Prevent ReDoS
body: To fix https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3359, modified reHasUnicodeWord to remove an unnecessary comma which made the regex greedy, this is only a test regex and not a matching regex. Added unit tests, this now should run under 5 ms instead of over 1000 ms for huge 50k+ char words.

title: Prevent ReDoS
body: To fix https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3359, modified reHasUnicodeWord to remove an unnecessary comma which made the regex greedy, this is only a test regex and not a matching regex. Added unit tests, this now should run under 5 ms instead of over 1000 ms for huge 50k+ char words. This fix was done at the RegEx level, without limiting the input size.

title: _.isAsyncFunction
body:
What about to add a new method like _.isAsyncFunction to check whether the function is an async function ?
Like MDN' doc: [AsyncFunction](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/AsyncFunction)

```js
function isAsyncFunction (value) {
  return value && value.constructor && value.constructor === Object.getPrototypeOf(async function(){}).constructor
}
```

title: array selection in "path" is better to support wildcard.
body:
Hi,

I have a object like this:

```javascript
{
  id: 123,
  title: 'ok, this is title',
  content: 'this is content',
  updatedAt: '2018-08-22',
  author: {
    id: 3322,
    name: 'Bill',
    level: 'high'
  },
  comments: [{
    id: 1,
    description: 'cool~',
    createdAt: '2018-08-20'
  }, {
    id: 2,
    description: 'awesome',
    createdAt: '2018-08-21'
  }]
}
```

What I'm going to do is to define a group of private fields. Using `omit`, for instance, I can define the `path`as `'id, updatedAt, author.id, comments[*].createdAt, comments[*].id'`, but it's not work for sub collection(the `comments` part).

I know I can implement it myself, it's better if `path` in `omit` supports deep collection.

Thanks!

title: takeRightWhile
body:
example:
```
var users = [
  { 'user': 'barney',  'active': true },
  { 'user': 'fred',    'active': false },
  { 'user': 'pebbles', 'active': false }
]
_.takeRightWhile(users, ['active', true])
```

The result of the output is []

title: [Meta] Keep issues open while in voting phase
body:
It isn't particularly useful to close issues that are deemed necessary to have votes cast on them. A vote usually implies there will be a decision _after_, not prior to the vote. It makes finding existing issues, which may duplicate what I want to suggest, harder to find and will lead to me not voting on an original issue someone is already waiting for votes on.

I propose you no longer just close issues and wait for them to actually be voted on, after a while, make the call to close or pursue the issue.

Hi,
First of all thanks for the library !

I am using the _sumBy function, and today I just found out that if it's used with an array of one element, it will return a boolean instead of a number, see this CodePen :
https://codepen.io/Kleemer/pen/oMrVeG
When it iterates in a list of more than one element then even if the answer is 1 (or 0) it won't return a boolean, I was just wondering if this is an expected behaviour ?

Thanks !

title: unescape should also handle &#039
body:
Currently, the lodash unescape function only unescapes &#39 for apostrophe. It should also handle &#039, as some escapings use this sequence with a leading zero.

Current code in lodash.js:
`var reEscapedHtml = /&(?:amp|lt|gt|quot|#39);/g,`

title: mergeWith: get the current path inside customizer function
When using .remove on array, splice is avoided causing array to not be reactive in vue
body: When you perform _.remove() on an array that contains only one element then instead of calling splice the array unsets the 0 property path. This causes bindings in vue to not react to this change.

title: Evaluate behavior of isEmpty
body:
I was testing something quite simple in my app, and I noticed that the `isEmpty` method might have a small flaw in one type of validation.
When the value of a variable or property of an object is zero, it returns that the input is empty
Ex:
```js
const number = 0
const obj = {
   number: 0
}

_.isEmpty(number) // true
_.isEmpty(obj.number) // true
```
Is this an expected behavior of the method?

Thanks!

Why second argument (predicate) in partition not get key as other similar method ?
body:
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.10#partition

A lot of method which work with collection have format like
`The predicate is invoked with three arguments: (value, index|key, collection).`
But partition is not, it have different format
`The predicate is invoked with one argument: (value).` 

Why?

title: Feature Request: _.queue
body:
Hi,

I think it's good to have a higher-order function to make an async function calls go one by one and keep them in a queue, so if there's still a pending promise from the last call, the new call should wait.
I hope i made my point clear and if it's not clear enough, I already made it work in [this commit](https://github.com/poonzah/lodash/commit/a0c08e2433125561fa77b9dc9d33393f3a02b181).

Any thumbs up for that?

title: isEmpty issues with FormData
body:

But when using the `form-data` polyfill in node it returns `false` for all cases

title: Potential Bug: _.has() with property names that include square brackets
body:
Hi,

I'm trying to test for the existence of a property whose name contains square brackets, but _.has() is checking for the property with the square brackets stripped instead.
That is:
```
const test = {
  foo: "bar"
};
console.log(_.has(test, "foo"));
console.log(_.has(test, "[foo]"));
```
Output:
```
true
true
```
I'm not sure if this is intended behaviour or counts as an edge case, but if it is intended, perhaps the documentation could be updated to describe it somewhere?

Thanks!

title: Question about _.sum implementation
Added reverse split functionality
body:
/**
 * Splits `string` by `separator`, but in reverse
 *
 * **Note:** This method is based on
 * [`split`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/split.js).
 *
 * @since 4.0.0
 * @category String
 * @param {string} [string=''] The string to split.
 * @param {RegExp|string} separator The separator pattern to split by.
 * @param {number} [limit] The length to truncate results to from the end.
 * @returns {Array} Returns the string segments.
 * @example
 *
 * rsplit('a-b-c', '-', 2)
 * // => ['b', 'c']
 */

title: how much smaller could lodash be if...
body:
These are hard questions to answer, but I'm curious. How much smaller would lodash be (minified and gzipped) if...

It was written either with typescript or flow? API flexibility might suffer, but a lot of type safety code could be removed.

It only supported modern browsers, say ie11 and evergreen latest - 2?

Lodash has so many advantages, but size often keeps it from being adopted which is a bummer.

title: Make a tiny optimization in `baseIsEqual()`
_.startCase does not handle slashes properly
body:
`startCase` does not seem to handle slashes properly - it strips them out despite that not being documented anywhere.

Here's a failing test case:

```js
let _ = require('lodash/fp')
let assert = require('assert')
assert.strictEqual(
  _.startCase('state university / college'),
  'State University / College'
)
```

And a `runkit` for convenient execution: https://runkit.com/daedalus28/lodash-start-case-slash-bug

title: forIn method fails for DOMRect objects in Firefox
Unify ES and CommonJS packages using pkg.main and pkg.module
body:
Currently I have the problem that I want to make use of tree shaking with Webpack + ES modules, but on the other hand I don't want to transpile my node_modules on the server.

This could be easily solved if lodash would specify a CommonJS module in the `main` field of `package.json` and an ES module in the `module` field. A perfect example of this is semantic-ui-react.

I think it is a little awkward having two separate packages for CommonJS and ES exports. I think it would be useful to have a build that unifies the two, now that it is possible.

I know this is a long shot, especially because I can just as well use babel-plugin-lodash, but I was just curious, would a setup like this make sense for the future?

title: Create an `unsetWith` or use splice instead of delete on arrays
_.template variable names
body:
Passing data to templates with keys that aren't valid JS variable names (but valid object property names) throws errors. Example:
```
const compiled = _.template('Some are like <%= this:var %>');
compiled({ 'this:var': ':(' });
```
This is kind of an edge case, but is caused by the `with` statement being used in compiled templates. A possible solution could be using property accessors with the bracket notation : `obj['this:var']` instead of `with (obj) { /* ... */ }` in compiled template functions? 
Saw some related issues that were closed ([most recent](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3709)) - and this would also 'fix' global variables being available in templates, which is, weird.
Would love to give this a go if it's considered useful.

title: lodash.pick module problems
body:
I recently refactored my code to make use of lodash modules instead of the big lodash library. Everything works fine, except the pick function.

I used to be able to do this:

_.pick(someObject, ['some.nestedKey']);

This used to return the right value.

But since I installed the NPM module lodash.pick (https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash.pick), this doesn't seem to work anymore! I'm still able to use simple prop names, but the dot notation doesn't return anything. I thought the .pick() function in the "big" lodash library and the one provided by lodash.pick module are supposed to be identical. Is this not true?

I mean, if I try to run the code example on the lodash website, dot notation works, but it doesn't work with the the module provided function.

I want to use the "modular lodash" (https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=keywords:lodash-modularized), so I can import only the functions I need. Are these modules not up-to-date?

Thanks in advance!

title: Option to let throttle and debounce wait until promise is resolved
body:
Basically the same as https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3863, but now our function is asynchronous and returns a promise.
Lodash should then wait until the promise is resolved and not re-trigger the execution until this is done.

title: Feature request: Option to let throttle and debounce wait until function executed
body:
It would be nice if these functions could – in addition to the time they usually wait – also wait until the function has been finished it's execution. I guess in most cases, you use throttle or debounce to prevent a function from running to often or so, so you certainly

E.g. we have a function that we throttle with 300ms, and it usually just takes 50ms, so it's all fine, but one time it may take 600ms. In such a case, throttle would trigger it again while it is still running.
And that's what we may not want.

title: _.mod
body:
Example Usage:

```javascript
-5 % 7 // => -5. This is incorrect behavior. This is "remainder", not modulo. This is a well understood issue
_.mod(-5, 7) // => 2. This is how far "above" the nearest multiple of 7 the number is, and is generally more useful.
```

The implementation is very simple (just `(a, b) => (a % b + b) % b`).

title: Update `filterObject` docs to reference `pickBy`
body: This is clearly an area of confusion -- see [this question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30726830/how-to-filter-keys-of-an-object-with-lodash) as an example. Hopefully this helps.
